author: Staff Writer
title: Coronation shares rally over 3% following trading update | Financial Services
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK Related articles Coronation: Crown may have wobbled but it’s still the king Coronation to stay on mandate despite dip Coronation shares drop again Coronation told to open up on employee remuneration CLM View company tearsheet SHARES in Coronation Fund Managers rallied over 3% on Monday after the company told shareholders in a voluntary trading statement that it expected a decline in its full-year earnings.
In the year ended September 2015, Coronation said diluted headline earnings per share (HEPS) were expected to fall between 5% and 15% from diluted HEPS of 571.6c reported in the year-earlier period.
"As detailed in our prior communications, Coronation is a cyclical business with a revenue stream that is highly geared to both the returns of the market and the level of outperformance generated in the funds it manages on behalf of clients," the company said.
"As per the communication for each calendar quarter end, shareholders are further advised that Coronation’s total assets under management as at 30 September 2015 are R610bn," the company said.
SA’s restrained economic growth, fluctuating rand, rising inflation and the current interest rates cycle are some of the factors which are likely to prolong pressure on local equity investments, said FNB Private Wealth and RMB Private Bank CEO Eric Enslin.
"This is a tough cycle and that can be seen in the number of companies which have shed value over a relatively short period, even though some have quickly recovered losses. Even more significant is the fact that various industries continue to predict an even tougher outlook which could see subdued future performance.
"Currently, a number of investors are possibly evaluating their exposure to equities, but in reality, equities remain one of the best performing asset classes for long-term investors. The long-term view is essential because any ill-considered reaction to short-term share-price movements could lead to losing hard-earned gains," said Mr Enslin.
At 10.51am, the share had come down from its early rise and was up 2.45% to R72.30, valuing the company at about R24.7bn.
In the past year, Coronation has seen a 23% decline in its market cap.
